results.title: Listen up my cherubs!
results.creator_credit: Karen Milward, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Energetic and intelligent, Karen Milward is constantly engaged with life. Often on the road for her work in the Aboriginal community, her children wonder what it is she actually does. This story is by way of explanation and gives insight into the life of an amazing community worker and consultant.

results.title: Listen to us - the way we speak. Part 1
results.creator_credit: Barbara Wethey and Inner London Education Authority
results.brief_description: Part 1. “Listen to us”: “Linguistic and Cultural Diversity”. Britain now has a multi-ethnic and multicultural society which is also multilingual. This program acknowledges that diversity in order to benefit pupils. Part 4. “The Way We Speak”: “Considering Dialect and Learning”. Considers whether schools should permit and teach dialects of the English language. In both of these programs we see activities which may help to develop and reinforce language, showing teachers using the activities in actual classrooms. Companion videotape “Working Together in the Classroom; Supporting Understanding”

results.title: Listen to steel
results.creator_credit: Daniel Ingram, Film Producers Guild and Interfilm
results.brief_description: Presents an impression of dynamic British industry. Illustrates the latest developments in plant and processes throughout the country, underlining the modern techniques and up-to-date equipment now being used to increase production and reduce costs.

results.title: Listen to me
results.creator_credit: Terrence Doran and Police and Community Video Project
results.brief_description: This kit is a useful new education resource designed to address social factors that undermine the formation of a healthy and respectful relationship between the police force and young people. It is a joint production of local police, young people and community from the inner urban area of Flemington/Kensington in Melbourne. The kit consists of a video and a set of linked, but autonomous education modules. The video is a realist documentary style production that aims to give a ‘slice of life’ view of a neighbourhood and its young people; police work in the neighbourhood; and situations of conflict of distrust that arise between young people and the police. The themes underpinning the video are picked up and expanded in the five specific education modules which include: young people, conflict and the police; high-rise living and the police; communication, cultural diversity and policing; young women and the police; the role of the police.

results.title: Listen to Britain
results.creator_credit: Humphrey Jennings and Crown Film Unit
results.brief_description: The sights and sounds of a people at war, told without commentary or dialogue - the roar of tanks and planes, the voices of children, the multi lingual radio commentators, Commonwealth soldiers, Flanagan and Allen singing “Underneath the Arches”, Myra Hess playing a Mozart concerto, a military brass band counterpointed with genius and affection to scenes in streets and factories and country places. This film is considered one of the most successful of the documentary films of Humphrey Jennings.

results.title: Listen please
results.creator_credit: Modern Management Films and Calvin Productions
results.brief_description: Supervisors learn the value of listening. It boosts their employees’ morale, keeps grievances to a minimum and assists in decision making. The obstacles to listening, such as being too preoccupied or busy must be recognised and overcome.

results.title: Listen hear
results.brief_description: Effective listening is a skill. This video program identifies and explains how we can improve our listening and highlights the four main listening techniques: listening with your whole body; rapport building; responding appropriately; removing barriers. The program is aimed at trainers/facilitators within organizations and includes a Trainer’s Manual.
